MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.
texts.en:
In 1994 three years after the collapse of USSR and the beginning of the reform, the family of Nazarkulovs was given a plot of land in several hectares. Being used to working for the collective good, for Nazarkulovs it was new to start their own business. Anarhan N. is 53 years old, she is a leader of this group. At her husband's initiative was the first to buy 2000 soms worth of cattle for breeding. Because agriculture is a seasonal source of income, animal husbandry turned out to be a good addition to the family's savings account. The winter time is a time off from agriculture, but Anarhan now has to take care of the animals. During winter the animals need special care more than in the summer time when the cattle can take care of itself.

Anarhan's husband is a hydraulics technician, they have a fifteen year old daughter who is financially dependent on them. Their older son is 25 and works in the Tashkumyrskiy GAO and also provides his share in the development of their family business.

The fifteen year term has justified Anarhan's anticipation. At this time the agriculture business together with animal husbandry bring Anarhan around 9500 soms of monthly income. As all the other farmers Anarhan is anxiously waiting for the beginning of the sowing season. The purchase of the fertilizer will be her main expense and this is why she wants to take out the loan.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for sowing

loans.name: Fernalin

texts.en:
Fernalin M. is from the village of Corrales, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old, and is married with 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Fernalin owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Fernalin has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Fernalin joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fernalin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,500 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to additional capital for her business. Fernalin is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seedlings and fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Fernalin from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seedlings and fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Marlene Maclovia

texts.es:
La Señora. Marlene C. es socia del banco comunal Loma de la Cruz, vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es patrimonio cultural de la humanidad desde 1999 gracias a su hermoso centro histórico, su gente mantienen su cultura y tradiciones, cuenta también con una gran variedad en su gastronomía.
 
Doña Marlene tiene 48 años de edad, es madre soltera de 6 hijos de 30, 26, 23, 21, 19 y 16 años de edad, sus tres primeros hijos son casados e independientes, su cuarto y quinto hijo trabajan y le ayudan economícamente, su ultimo hijo estudia en un colegio de la ciudad. No tiene casa propia por lo que vive arrendando.
 
La Señora. Marlene es comerciante, se dedica a la venta de cosméticos de la marca Yanbal y también ropa, todas sus ventas las hace bajo pedido y esta labor la realiza hace 20 años, trabaja de lunes a viernes sin un horario fijo y vende recorriendo la ciudad  a sus amigos y conocidos.
 
Es socia del banco comunal hace nueve años y medio, el dinero de su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de cosméticos y ropa para su selecta clientela.

Su mayor sueño es viajar por todo el mundo.
texts.en:
Marlene C. is a member of the 'Loma de la Cruz' community bank.  She lives in the city of Cuenca which was named a World Heritage Site in 1999 thanks to its beautiful historic center.  Its people maintain their culture and traditions and its cuisine is very wide ranging.

Marlene is 48 years old.  She is a single mother and has six children aged 30, 26, 23, 21, 19 and 16.  Her three eldest children are married and live independently.  Her fourth and fifth children work and help her financially, and her youngest is attending high school.  She does not own her own home but lives in a rental home.

Marlene is a saleswoman.  She sells Yanbal cosmetics and clothes.  She makes all her sales to order and has been in the business for 20 years.  She works from Monday to Friday but does not work fixed hours.  She makes her sales door to door to her friends and acquaintances.

Marlene has been a member of her community bank for nine and a half years.  She will invest the money from her new loan in buying cosmetics and clothes for her select customers.

Marlene's biggest dream is to travel around the world.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and clothes

loans.name: Mohamed Unisa

texts.en:
Mohamed Unisa, age 39, established his mobile phone and accessories business in 2006.  Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about Le 500,000 every month from this business. He and his wife have one child. He also has one additional dependent who lives with the family. 

He would like to request a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000  in order to buy more mobile phones and accessories to offer for sale. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 200,000.  In the future, Mohamed Unisa plans to build a house, buy a car, and transform his kiosk into a much larger shop. He hopes to be able to educate his child to university level.   

He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more mobile phones and accessories to offer for sale

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto is a hard-working father to kids aged 17 and 9. He is a married man who lives in Surallah, South Cotabato with his family.

Roberto is engaged in farming and hog-raising businesses. He primarily grows rice crops to sell. Roberto raises his pigs in his backyard piggery. He earns about 10,000 PHP per month from doing these activities. He wants to improve his earnings and be able to save for his children's future.

Roberto plans to use his loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Katimama

texts.en: Katimama is 28 years old, married, and has two children who are in school. He has been practicing mixed farming (including sheep rearing and wheat farming) for the past seven years.  He learned about KADET LTD through KADET staff. He repaid his first loan successfully and applied for his second loan of KES 30,000, which he plans to spend partly on his farming and partly on purchasing more sheep.  He hopes to use the anticipated profits from his loan to educate his children. He dreams of expanding his farming.

loans.use: to improve his farming operation and to purchase more sheep

loans.name: Davron

texts.en:
Davron is dedicated to the rearing of cattle. He carries out this work every day for the purpose of improving the living conditions for his family, bringing the daily bread to his table, and saving for the improvement of his dwelling, which needs a lot of help because it is in a bad state. His family admires him for the fact that his multiple efforts have permitted him to feed them and provided them with good living conditions.  

Davron wants to develop and invest in his business through the purchase of more cows.   He hopes that IMON International, with the help of Kiva, will offer him the loan needed to expand his business.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: purchase more young cattle

loans.name: Usaha Jaya 8 Group

texts.en:
Elli is 39 years old, is married, and has three children. She lives with her family in Kalibaru, Cilincing, Jakarta.
She makes and sells "green banana" foods with bananas as the main ingredient, cooked with with angel hair and flour. She requested 2,000,0000 Indonesian rupiah to buy more ingredients such as bananas, angel hair, and flour for her business. 
She hopes to continue making and selling this food to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients such as bananas, angel hair, and flour.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to make orders for shoes she sells via catalog.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.es:
Eugenia es socia del  Banco Comunal “Virgen de la Asunción”, ubicado en el distrito y provincia de Yunguyo, departamento de Puno, tiene 57 años de edad, está casada y tiene 6 hijos (4 independientes).  Estudió hasta 5to de educación primaria.
Eugenia se dedica a  la venta de animales caseros y ganados ovinos y vacunos.  Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace ocho  años.  Su primer préstamo fue por  la suma  de S/ 300.00 nuevo soles, dinero que invirtió en su negocio de venta de animales caseros.
Con éste nuevo préstamo de S/  3000.00 nuevo soles, comprará un toro, una vaca, ovejas y forraje  para su engorde por tres meses.  Ella los compra en Huacullani.  También se dedica a la crianza de gallinas, chanchos y cuyes.  La señora trabaja sola en el negocio, su esposo trabaja en el Municipio.
Su sueño es tener más capital para tener buenos ganados y obtener más ganancias.
Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal es la organización y la comprensión de su promotora.
texts.en:
Eugenia is a member of the communal bank "Virgen de la Asunción” (Virgin of the Assumption), located in the district and province of Yunguyo, in the department of Puno. She is 57 years old. She is married and has 6 children (4 independent). She went to school up to the 5th year of primary education.

Eugenia works in the sale of home-raised animals, sheep, and cattle. She has worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for eight years. Her first loan was for the sum of 300 PEN, money which she invested in her business of selling home-raised animals. With this new loan of 3000 PEN, she will buy a bull, a cow, sheep, and fodder to fatten them for three months. She buys them in Huacullani. She also raises chickens, hogs, and guinea pigs. She works in her business alone; her husband works for the municipality. Her dream is to have more capital in order to have good livestock and to obtain more earnings.

What she likes about the communal bank is the organization and the understanding of her loan officer.

loans.use: to buy a bull, a cow, sheep, and fodder to fatten them

loans.name: Clement

texts.en:
Clement is 35 years old; married to Faith. They are blessed with one child aged three years. Clement has been in the spare part selling business for the past nine years with a monthly income of KES 8000 which he uses to support his family needs.

He is applying for his first loan with KADET after being introduced by an existing KADET customer. He will use his loan to add a stock of spare parts to his business inventory. 

With the anticipated profit from the business he will open a car wash business. His hopes and dreams are expanding the two businesses which will improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To add a stock of spare parts to his business inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy corn to make banku to sell

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
As a married mother of three children, Estrella works hard to support her family.

She has a shell craft making business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from the selling of personal products. Estrella is borrowing PHP 14,000 through Kiva partner NWTF in order to buy materials for her shell craft business.

Estrella has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy materials for her shell craft making business.

loans.name: Akylai's Group

texts.en:
Akylai is the leader of this group. She is 42 and together with her husband she raises five children: two daughters and three sons. The daughters are students, the older son helps in cattle breeding and the other two sons are preschool age (under seven). In order to earn money to meet the family's needs Akylai breeds cattle and sells dairy products. She applied for this loan because she needs additional funds to repair her house. In the near future she wants to build a shed to keep cattle and with the profits gained from the business she wishes to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to repair her house.

loans.name: Laarni

texts.en:
Laarni is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. 

Laarni has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Laarni has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Laarni hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Jackie

texts.en:
Jackie, a 30-year-old married mother of one child who is currently in school, lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. For the past five years, Jackie has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells pesticides, fertilizers and other farming supplies.

To help expand her business, Jackie has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase seeds and other farming supplies for resale, purchases that will help her to generate greater profits and impove her quality of life. She hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a wholesale soap shop and become one of the biggest suppliers in her area.

Jackie is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jackie who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and other farming supplies for resale.

loans.name: Luís Ramon

texts.es:
El señor Luís tiene 70 años de edad, es casado con cinco hijos.

Él se dedica a la agricultura desde los 16 años de edad, su papá fue quien le enseño a trabajar, ya que esta era la única actividad que ellos desarrollaban. 

Don Luís necesita de insumos, para que sus cultivos se puedan desarrollar, por lo que se traslada a la ciudad en busca de ellos, para llegar ahí tiene que caminar a pie quince minutos hasta llegar a un lugar donde aborda un carro y se va en la palangana de este durante cuarenta minutos hasta llegar al lugar donde compra los insumos agrícolas.

Él solicita un préstamo a Fundación Campo, para comprar: fertilizantes, herbicidas, insecticidas, entre otros. Con los cuales dará mantenimiento a tiempo a una manzana de maíz (7000 metros cuadrados) que tiene sembrada. Con el préstamo el saldrá a tiempo para no perder los frutos,  y la producción será buena, con la que estaría asegurando la alimentación de su familia. 

Don Luís, espera ampliar el área de cultivo, para producir más y por ende obtener mejores ingresos y poder dar a su familia todo lo necesario.
texts.en:
Luis is 70 years old and is married with 5 children.
He has farmed since the age of 16.  His father taught him this work, as it was the only work he knew.
Luis needs supplies for his crops to develop.  He must go to the city in search of them.  It takes 15 minutes on foot to get to where he can board a car.  Then it takes 40 minutes to get to the place where they sell farming supplies.
He requests the loan from Fundación Campo to buy fertilizer, herbicides, insecticides, and more, with which he will maintain an area of corn (7000 square meters) that he has planted.  With the loan, he will be able to pick the fruit on time and the production will be good and he will be able to feed his family.
Luis hopes to increase his crop area to produce more and get better income and be able to give his family everything they need.

loans.use: buy fertilizer, herbicides, insecticides, and other supplies needed to grow corn.

loans.name: Odzi Group

texts.en:
Gloria is 56 years old and has been running her own businesses for many years.  Currently, she makes money from two activities: buying and selling clothes in the local market and raising chickens.

Both businesses are going well but the clothing business is in decline because import restrictions and duties are making the import of clothes less profitable.

Gloria has borrowed $400 and will use the money to buy day old chicks and fund her cross-border transactions. She hopes that the profit will enable her to fund her son's college education. She dreams that one day she will have her own boutique.

loans.use: to purchase clothes and day old chicks to raise

loans.name: Almaisa

texts.en:
Almaisa is married and has two kids. She is 24 years old and lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. Almaisa sells fish in their barangay to make a living and has had this business for more than five years. Each month, she spends Php 5,000 to purchase more fish to sell in the market. She has requested a loan of Php 7,000 to buy new equipment and tools for fishing and to buy more fish to sell. Almaisa has been a member of GDMPC for more than a year.

In the future, Almaisa plans to save for the education of her two kids and to sustain their daily needs every day. She is hoping that her business will grow.

loans.use: to buy new equipment and tools for fishing.

loans.name: Le

texts.en:
Le is a 43-year-old married woman who lives in Ho Chi Minh City. She has two children. Her husband lives with her and supports the family by running a cafe and selling mobile phones.

Le earns an income by selling newspapers and magazines. She has done this for 10 years. Le is asking for a loan because she intends to buy a display case from which to sell her papers and related products. She hopes this will enable her to attract additional customers and generate a higher income. She hopes that this will help her to improve her family's living conditions and enable her to save money for her children's education.

loans.use: To buy a display case from which to sell her papers and related products.

loans.name: Santa Rosa Group

texts.es:
El Comité "Santa Rosa"  D. la ciudad D. Villa Ygatimi. Están en el primer Ciclo del Programa Comité D. Mujeres Rurales D. la Fundación Paraguaya con el total D. Diez integrantes. Todas son mujeres responsables y dedicadas, que diariamente se esfuerzan para que por medio D. trabajo puedan ayudar a sus familias e hijos, son jefas D. hogar que cargan con la responsabilidad D. cuidar a sus familias.
Una D. ellas es la señora Juana, quien se dedica a la cría D. gallinas desD. hace ya un buen tiempo. Ella comenta comenta que su trabajo es muy sacrificado ya que siempre debe D. estar pendiente para que sus animales no tengan ninguna enfermedad. Ella comenta que venD. bien los animales que cría, por lo que quiere seguir invirtiendo en ello.
Solicita el crédito para la compra D. gallinas pequeñas para la cría y posterior venta, además D. eso para comprar alimento para los mismos. Agradecen la oportunidad que la fundación les da.
texts.en:
The Santa Rosa Communal Bank of the city of Villa Ygatimí is in the first loan cycle of the Programa Comité D. Mujeres Rurales, of the Fundación Paraguaya, with a total of ten members.  All are responsible and dedicated women who make an effort through their work every day so they can help their families and children.  They are heads of household who bear the responsibility of taking care of their families. 

One of the members is Juana, who has worked raising chickens for a long time already.  She comments that her work is very selfless, since she always has to devote her time to her animals so they do not get any illness.  She says the animals she raises sell well, which is why she wants to continue investing in them.

She is requesting the loan to buy little chickens to raise and later sell.  She also will buy feed for them.

She is grateful for the opportunity that the foundation is giving her.

loans.use: to buy animals to raise and feed for them.

loans.name: Gloria Maria

texts.es:
Gloria de 45 años de edad, es casada, tiene  3 hijos de 26,19 y 15 años de edad todos ellos están estudiando en la actualidad, ella es comerciante tiene una pulpería en su casa de habitación, vive en la ciudad de Granada. Empezó su negocio con la ayuda de su esposo con el objetivo de generar otros ingresos que le ayudara a solventar algunos gastos que en su momento no podían pagar pero el negocio fue creciendo poco a poco de la misma manera fue surtiéndolo de mas productos de mucho uso y necesidad para  su vecindario. Ahora se siente muy satisfecha por que es independiente genera sus propios ingresos aporta en el hogar y cuida su familia, lleva 16 años con este negocio. 
Ella realizo el crédito para compra de mercadería tales como arroz, frijoles, aceite, azúcar, cosméticos, jugos, papel de baño, gaseosas, pan, galletas. Ella esta ahorrando para la graduación de sus hijos pues es una de sus metas principales así como lograr hacer mas sostenible su negocio. Por lo pronto desea seguir trabajando y cancelar su crédito.
texts.en:
Gloria is 45 years old and married. She has 3 children aged 26, 19 and 15 years old, all of whom are currently studying. 

She is a shopkeeper and has a grocery store in her home where she lives in the city of Granada. She started her business with the help of her husband, with the goal of generating additional income that would help her pay some expenses that at the moment they couldn't pay. However, the business grew little by little and at the same time was supplying much needed products for her neighborhood. Now, she feels very satisfied because she is independent, and generates her own income to support her home and care for her family. She has had this business for 16 years. She attained this loan in order to buy merchandise such as rice, beans, cooking oil, sugar, cosmetics, juices, toilet paper, sodas, bread and cookies. 

She is saving for her children's graduations, as it is one of her main goals, along with making her business more sustainable. In the meantime, she wants to continue working and pay back her loans.

loans.use: to buy merchandise such as rice, beans, cooking oil, sugar, cosmetics, juices, toilet paper, sodas, bread and cookies.

loans.name: Ecelyn

texts.en:
Ecelyn, 48, is married and has six children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Ecelyn has a meat vending business in the Philippines. Ecelyn has been in this business for 3 years. 

Ecelyn requested a PHP 27,000 loan through NWTF to buy pigs for her meat vending business. In the future, Ecelyn would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy pigs for her meat vending business.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.es: La socia continua con su negocio de compra y venta de verduras y también en esta epoca la socia se dedica  a la crianza de animales menores, la socia desea en esta ocasión invertir el prestamo en la compra de cuyes en un numero aproximado de 50 y también invertir en la compra de 50 gallinas, la socia cría estos animales los engorda y algunas veces logra reproducirlos y los vende al doble o 3 veces mas el precio inicial. La socia solicita el prestamo para invertir en la compra de cuyes 50 y de 50 gallinas.
texts.en: Luisa keeps on running her activity, breeding small animals. In this occasion she is requesting a loan to invest it in the purchase of around 50 “cuyes” (“cuy” is Quechua for Guinea pig), as well as in the purchase of 50 hens. She breeds these animals, she fattens them and sometimes she successfully makes them mate, and she sells them at a price twice or 3 times higher than their basic price. She is requesting a loan to invest it in the purchase of 50 cuyes and 50 hens.

loans.use: To buy 50 cuyes and 50 hens.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Para Mejor Futuro Group

texts.en:
Lorenza is the coordinator of her group, Mujeres unidas para un futuro mejor (women unite for a better future). She lives in a simple structure with her three children. She says that her most difficult challenge was to get capital to start a business and to build her house. In the meantime, she plans to continue enjoying attending church.

Lorenza is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business, where she sells jewelry, by purchasing rings, bracelets, necklaces, and other women's accessories.  She will start her business with this loan, and she is exciting to work and develop her business. She will use her business profits to reinvest in her business.

Lorenza lives in a zone of little resources in the city of Santiago, which is one of the most populated in the Dominican Republic.  She is a very hard worker and an enthusiastic woman.  Thanks for supporting this group of entrepreneurs!

loans.use: to buy jewelery.

loans.name: Lorie

texts.en:
Lorie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF in order to buy more fish to sell to her customers.

Lorie successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

NWTF is listing Lorie's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha the heads BOWODA women's group in Buchanan. They successfully completed their first loan of $485, selling 24 clean cookstoves.  Now the women group seeks to obtain more clean cookstoves and also solar lighting, solar lanterns, and solar phone charging to sell in their communities.  The profits go toward funding activities thatempower women, like education, entrepreneur training, and business loans.

loans.use: To pay for Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) products at wholesale to sell retail.

loans.name: Faustin

texts.en:
Faustin is 4 years old. He is married with four children aged between 3 and 12 years, 2 of them go to school. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past 30 years. His wife is also a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees of his children and to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Emanuel Group

texts.en:
Chichicastenango is well-known for its twice weekly market as well as the very colorful and ornate traditional clothing of the people. The market is huge and stretches for blocks.   Visitors from Guatemala and from far off places find a wide variety of traditional clothing and beautiful handicrafts. Vendors come from all parts of Guatemala to take advantage of the crowds of tourists who flock there. The entire experience is a feast for the senses.

The Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Emanuel” was formed by seven women in the town. The ladies have various businesses including jewelry and clothing sales, the sale of medicines and the sales of food items. Zonia, who is President of the group, is 65 years old, married and has five children. Zonia was able to stay in school until the 6th grade and is very aware of the value of a good education. She works hard at her little boarding house so that she can afford to send each of her children to the university. She charges by the month and includes meals in the price for a room. Zonia also has a textile business and makes napkins, table cloths and embroidered pillowcases. She is requesting a loan that she will use to buy a refrigerator, tables, curtains and sheets. Zonia wants to be certain that her guests are well-cared for and comfortable. Because of previous loans and earnings, she has been able to enlarge her house and offer more rooms to her guests.

Each month, Zonia welcomes the ladies to the meeting and the first order of business is to take care of payments on the loans. Next, a Facilitator from Friendship Bridge conducts an educational training using games, diagrams, role playing and pictures. Most of the women have had little or no formal education.  If they do not speak Spanish, the training is conducted in the native language of the women. 

KIVA investors are greatly valued by Zonia and the women of the Trust Bank for providing funding for their loans. Armed with their new tools, they are already stepping into a brighter future benefitting themselves, their families and their community in Chichicastenango. Thank you!

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator, tables, curtains and sheets.

loans.name: Manuela Oralia

texts.en:
Manuela is very dynamic woman. She is a widower as of few years ago, and she decided to start a small business of making art picture sales (especially religious pictures) to help her generate her own income and with this income make her living and educate her son. She started selling her products to her friends and little by little her business grew. Now she has an excellent portfolio of clients that constantly want to buy her products. Manuela’s idea is to obtain a loan of US $475 to purchase raw materials for her business and maintain a stock of pictures for her clients. She hopes to pay this loan in 6-12 months.

**"This text has been translated from the following original business description."

Doña Manuela es una mujer muy dinámica, quedó viuda hace algunos años y decidió iniciar un pequeño negocio de venta de cuadros de arte (especialemente de motivos religiosos)para ayudarse generando sus propios ingresos y así poder sacar adelante a su hijo que estaba estudiando y no quería que descuidara sus estudios. Ella inició vendiendo con sus conocidos y poco a poco fue aumentando sus clientes hasta tener una cartera ya formada que permanentemente le solicita productos. La idea de Manuela es poder contar con un préstamo por $ 475 USD para poder comprar la materia prima para sus productos y así poder ofrecérselos a sus clientes para seguir contando con su preferencia, el plazo para pagar será de 6-12 meses.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Gladys would like to buy 8 steers

loans.name: Eliud Wangila

texts.en:
Eliud is a young man who is not yet married. He started his hawking business in 2005 after secondary school. He is also a farmer specializing in tobacco, where he works hand-in-hand with his father. Through his business, he has been able to support his parents to pay school fees for his sibling.

With the loan of $150 from PEMCI, he intends to increase his stock of utensils and kitchenware. This way he will be able to move to different markets, hence expanding his sales and profits. As a youth, Eliud is a good role model for those aspiring to start their own businesses. In view of the unemployment situation, many youth are encouraged to seek self-employment as a way of earning their livelihood. Well worth the support of Kiva partners.

loans.use: To increase capital

loans.name: Uch

texts.en: Mrs. Uch N. is 38 years old (she stands in the middle of this picture) and lives with her husband and two nieces in a part of the Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She and her husband are both farmers growing rice crops and a variety of vegetables in their rice paddy. This activity typically contributes around $2 each day to the household, while her two nieces help in generating more income by working at one of the garment factories in the city. Mrs. Uch N. currently needs a motorcycle to assist in transporting their outputs from the paddy to the market, where she can sell them. The couple believes the loan will play a very important role for the family.

loans.use: Needs a motorcycle to assist in transporting her outputs to a market.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia lives on Avenue Mario Mercado in the Bautista Saavedra zone in the city of El Alto. She has three small children, ages 9, 2, and 3 months. She works with furniture which she sells at different markets in the city of El Alto. Her husband, due to lack of work, had to emigrate to Argentina, where he currentl works as a tailor.

The loan will be invested in the purchase of raw material (wood, glue, varnish, etc.) to continue her business and try to increase sales and improve the family's economic situation.

This is her second loan with Impro. The first was invested in the purchase of tools to increase her production. Currently, that loan is paid in full.

The evaluation conducted qualifies Julia for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Julia vive en la avenida Mario Mercado de la zona Bautista Saavedra de la ciudad de el Alto. Tiene tres hijos pequeños de 9, 2 años y uno de 3 meses, se dedica a la elaboración de muebles los cuales los comercializa en las diferentes ferias de la ciudad de El Alto. Su esposo, por falta de trabajo, tuvo que emigrar a la Republica de Argentina donde actualmente trabaja como costurero. El crédito será invertido en la compra de materia prima (madera, cola, barniz, etc.) para continuar con su negocio y tratar de incrementar sus ventas y mejorar los ingresos económicos en su familia. Es el segundo crédito con Impro, El primero lo invirtió en la compra de herramientas para el mejor desempeño en su trabajo; actualmente dicho préstamo esta pagado en su totalidad. La evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo

loans.use: Purchase raw materials - wood, glue, varnish

loans.name: Aura Lila

texts.es:
Mrs. Jiménez has a small shop located on the edge of the central market of León. The business has been in existence for a little more than six years. She has worked hard and sacrificed, because she previously sold general merchandise (clothing, shoes, gold, etc.), which she brought from Panamá.

Following a very painful event in her life, which was the horrific murder of her only son, she fell into a terrible depression and her business went downhill. After recovering from this difficult loss, she started selling inexpensive clothing and costume jewelry on a sidewalk in the central market with $200.00 of capital. After a year she was able to get into the shop where she is now located. Mrs. Jiménez has two daughters, 20 and 25 years old, for whom she is providing. They are studying Medicine and Pharmacy in the UNAN (National Autonomous University or Nicaragua). She has been working with CEPRODEL for more than 2 years.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Esta señora posee un pequeño módulo ubicado en las afueras del mercado central de León. El negocio tiene poco más de seis años de existencia. La historia de esta señora ha sido de mucho esfuerzo y sacrificio, ya que anteriormente, ella se dedicaba a la comercialización de mercadería en general la cual traía de Panamá (ropa, zapatos, oro, etc.

Luego de un acontecimiento muy doloroso en su vida en el cual le asesinan atrozmente a su único hijo varón, ella cae en una depresión terrible y su negocio de viene abajo, luego de reponerse de este duro golpe, ella establece un pequeño puesto de ropa barata y bisutería en la acera del mercado central, con un pequeño capital de aproximadamente US$ 200 dólares. Luego de un año de lucha logra conseguir el local en donde ella ahora se encuentra ubicada. La señora Jiménez tiene a dos hijas a su cargo de 25 y 20 años respectivamente, las cuales cursan sus estudios de Medicina y Farmacia en la UNAN (Universidad Nacional Autónoma de Nicaragua). Ella tiene más de 2 años de trabajar con CEPRODEL.

loans.use: To buy merchandise (loan of $1900.00)

loans.name: Pair Mohammad

texts.en: Pair Mohammad lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has a retail shop. He has been engaged in business for over 6 years. He is married and has 4 children. His business is located in the main city of Kabul. He has lots of clients, but he has few materials in his shop. He wants to take an individual loan to buy extra materials like bars of chocolate, sweets, and baskets to make a good monthly income and help his family more. He is happy with all parts of his family.

loans.use: To buy extra materials like bars of chocolate, sweets, and baskets.

loans.name: Dinh Thi

texts.vi:
Young and industrious, Mrs. Đinh Thị Bắc, 35 years of age, though recently, 2004, joined the TYM Fund, has been active of taking out loans to invest in her business. Her general store carries variety of goods to satisfy the needs for people in the neighborhood. High quality, low price has resulted in her store’s popularity. The income is steady at 150USD a month. She would like to get a new loan of 1200USD to purchase more goods for her store. Mrs. Đinh Thị Bắc lives with her husband and 2 children in Vĩnh Yên, Vĩnh Phúc province.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Là một phụ nữ trẻ nhưng chị Đinh Thị Bắc, 35 tuổi rất năng động. Mới tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2004 nhưng chị đã mạnh dạn vay những mức vốn lớn đầu tư cho kinh doanh. Cửa hàng của chị bán nhiều loại hàng hóa phục vụ nhu cầu đa dạng của người dân trong vùng. Với chất lượng hàng tốt giá cả phải chăng nên cửa hàng của chị Bắc thu hút rất đông khách. Thu nhập của cửa hàng đạt 150USD/tháng. Mong muốn của chị Bắc là sẽ được vay tiếp 1200USD ở vòng vốn tới để mua thêm hàng. Hiện chị Bắc đang sống cùng chồng và hai con tại Vĩnh Yên, Vĩnh Phúc.

loans.use: Buy goods for general store

loans.name: Marcela José

texts.es:
Marcela L. is a very hardworking person who sells toys, apples, grapes, porcelain teacups, stemware, cosmetics, jewelry, grains, etc. In short, she has been operating a general store in the city of Leon for 8 years.

Her biggest motivation for having this business is her two small children whom she loves very much. She affirms that her greatest wish is to see them earn a university degree so that they can be successful in life. Despite having gone through rough times, financially speaking, Marcela has requested loans from Ceprodel in order to meet her needs, thus getting ahead in her general store. She has requested a total of 8 loans.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Marcela L. es un apersona muy esforzada que se dedica a la venta de juguetes, manzanas, uvas, tasas de porcelana, copas de vidrio, cosméticos, bisuterías, granos básicos, etc. En fin es una tienda de víveres que la administra desde hace 8 años en la ciudad de Leon.

Su mayor motivo para seguir con este negocio han sido sus dos pequeños a los que ama mucho y afirma que son sus mayores deseos que ellos coronen una carrera universitaria para ser personas de éxito en la vida. A pesar de haber pasado por momentos muy complicados hablando financieramente, Marcela ha solicitado créditos en Ceprodel para apoyarse en sus necesidades y de esta manera salir adelante en su negocio de víveres. Su record crediticio es de 8 créditos.

loans.use: Purchase of materials

loans.name: Yu

texts.en: Mrs. Yu S., 26, is a mother of one school-aged child, and works as a farmer. Normally, she earns $1 a day from her work. Her husband, Mr. Long Sei, 37, works making jars and sells them from door to door or in the market. Every day he can earn around $5 a day of profit. In order to increase the quantity of her husband's jar sales, Yu is requesting a loan for her husband from Kiva to purchase tools for making the jars.

loans.use: To purchase tools for making jars.

loans.name: Hortensia

texts.es:
Hortensia Cárdenas, like many women in our country, has had to confront alone the responsibility of educating and supporting her 3 small children. Worried about the situation that she faced of having to work, but not wanting to neglect her children, she started to sell food to her neighbors 3 years ago. Thanks to her exquisite seasoning, she was able to start her business and make it grow. Now she has a large number of customers.

She needs a credit of $300, which she will repay in 3 months, to purchase supplies to make her food. Let's support Hortensia so she can take good care of her children.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Hortensia Cárdenas como muchas mujeres en nuestro país ha tenido que enfrentar sola la responsabilidad de educar y mantener a sus 3 pequeños hijos, preocupada por la situación que enfrentaba al tener que trabajar pero no querer descuidar a su hijos hace 3 años empezó a vender comida a sus vecinos y gracias a su exquisito sazón es que pudo iniciar su negocio haciéndolo crecer y ahora abarca un mayor numero de comensales.

Ella necesita un crédito por US $300 que pagara en 3 meses para la compra de materia prima para la elaboración de sus comidas. Apoyemos a hortensia para que pueda sacar adelante a sus hijos.

loans.use: To purchase supplies

loans.name: Olinda

texts.es:
The Conima district is Olinda's native village. Olinda is a 26-year-old young mother who, thanks to her effort and willpower, is helping her family get ahead, in partnership with her husband Leonardo. Olinda operates a mobile vegetable cart in the Tupac Amaru market of the city in which she currently lives. When she realized that the income from her business was insufficient to cover her needs, she decided to buy two tricycles that she could rent out in order to obtain extra income to maintain her home and, above all, to educate her two youngest children. Thanks to the investment she made, she is improving her economic situation and hopes to expand her vegetable stall. Olinda believes that with this change, she and her family's quality of life will improve even more.

Translated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva volunteer

El distrito de Conima, es el pueblo natal de Olinda, joven madre de 26 años de edad, que a fuerza de empeño y voluntad viene sacando adelante a su familia junto a su querido esposo Leonardo. Olinda se dedica a la venta de verduras en forma ambulatoria en el mercado Túpac Amaru de la ciudad en la que ahora radica.Al ver que los ingresos que obtenía con su negocio no cubrían todas sus necesidades decidió comprar 2 triciclos para alquilarlos y obtener ingresos extras para el sustento de su hogar y sobre todo para la educación de sus 2 menores hijos.Gracias a la inversión que hizo está logrando mejorar su situación económica y tiene proyectado ampliar su puesto de venta de verduras, Olinda cree que con este cambio mejorará aún más su calidad de vida y la de su familia.

loans.use: Capital increase to improve her workspace

loans.name: Rosa Patricia

texts.es:
Rosa Patricia is a young 29 year old mom of 2 kids aged 10 and 13 years. She lives with her family in the area of Laureles Sur in the city of Managua. She is married and her husband works as a builder, working for himself. Most of the time he out of the house looking for contracts to take on in order to earn the income he needs, so that together with Rosa Patricia, they may be able to support their family.

Rosa works as a supervisor in a factory, a position she managed to get with a great deal of hard work and dedication. Among her many dreams, she wishes to provide her children with an education, to offer them a better quality of life, and she would also like to renovate their home. For this reason she requests a loan, and with it she will be able to finish the renovation construction to the front of their house.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosa Patricia es una joven madre de 29 años de edad, tiene 2 hijos de 10 y 13 años. Habita junto a su familia en el barrio Laureles Sur de Managua. Es casada, su esposo se dedica al oficio de albañilería, trabaja por cuenta propia, la mayor parte del tiempo está fuera de su casa en busca de trabajo que le dé los ingresos necesarios para que junto a Rosa Patricia puedan dar el sustento a su familia. Rosa trabaja como supervisora en una zona franca, puesto que logró obtener con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación. Entre sus sueños está el poder darle educación a sus hijos, ofrecerles una mejor calidad de vida, y también desea poder mejorar su hogar, es por eso que solicita el préstamo, terminará de construir la pared frontal de su casa de habitación.

loans.use: To complete renovation construction to the front of their house.

loans.name: Rachid

texts.en: Rachid , 55, lives in the eastern suburbs of Beirut. As a handicapped father, he raises his 4 children from the only income he has, afforded by an internet café that he is always trying to improve. For this goal, he needs a loan in the amount of US$ 1,000 to redecorate the internet café and to purchase new computers. This is the first time that Rachid has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: to redecorate and purchase new computers

loans.name: Rosa Leonor

texts.es:
Rosita, as her neighbors and clients call her lovingly, is a caring, and responsible mother completely dedicated to her family. Ever since she became married, she decided she would abandon her native town of Yunguyo and look for better job opportunities. It is so that she now lives in the city of Juliaca, and is satisfied by counting on the unconditional support of her husband and their two children, who give her the strength needed to continue her business. She sells a variety of socks; merchandise which she obtains in the city of Desaguadero, and then sells in the cities of Cuzco and Arequipa. Her husband works providing transportation to those cities. Rosita’s dream is to increase her merchandise, and not only sell socks, but undergarments for women, men, and children. She is sure that with your support and this investment she will be able to better her business.

Translated into English by Patricia Yanez, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosita, como cariñosamente la llaman sus vecinos y clientes, es una madre amorosa, responsable y dedicada a su familia, desde que contrajo matrimonio decidió abandonar su pueblo natal Yunguyo y buscar mejores oportunidades de trabajo, es así, que radica en la ciudad de Juliaca, actualmente tiene la satisfacción de contar con el apoyo incondicional de esposo y sus 2 niños, quienes le dan las fuerzas suficientes para continuar con su negocio, ella vende variedad de calcetines, mercadería que adquiere en la ciudad de Desaguadero y la vende en la ciudades de Cuzco y Arequipa. Su esposo trabaja brindando servicio de transporte departamental a dichas ciudades, el deseo de Rosita es aumentar su mercadería, y no sólo vender calcetines, sino también, ropa interior para damas, caballeros y niños. Está segura que con tu apoyo y esta inversión podrá mejorar su negocio.

loans.use: To increase merchandise for her clothes sales business.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.es:
Faustina G. is separated and has a four year old daughter named Milagro, which means Miracle in Spanish. She operates a hair salon and variety store out of her house in a small neighborhood on the outskirts of the main capital, Asunción. Faustina says her hair salon gets good business, especially during the weekends, when clients come to get their hair done for the following week. She also sells hair products, cosmetics, herbal medicines, and children’s toys to earn additional income. Outside the entrance to Faustina’s salon, her daughter Milagro has set up her own make-believe shop, where she pretends to make cakes while her mother is working.

Faustina has been a client with Fundacion Paraguaya for more than five years. She began by working in a small women’s group loan program, and took out her first individual loan four years ago. Since then she has made every loan payment on time. She is asking for 2,000,000 Gs to buy additional products for her salon and store.
texts.en:
Faustina G. is separated and has a four year old daughter named Milagro, which means Miracle in Spanish. She operates a hair salon and variety store out of her house in a small neighborhood on the outskirts of the main capital, Asunción. Faustina says her hair salon gets good business, especially during the weekends, when clients come to get their hair done for the following week. She also sells hair products, cosmetics, herbal medicines, and children's toys to earn additional income. Outside the entrance to Faustina's salon, her daughter Milagro has set up her own make-believe shop, where she pretends to make cakes while her mother is working.

Faustina has been a client with Fundacion Paraguaya for more than five years. She began by working in a small women's group loan program, and took out her first individual loan four years ago. Since then she has made every loan payment on time. She is asking for 2,000,000 Gs to buy additional products for her salon and store.


Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy additional products for her salon and store

loans.name: Gran Poder Group

texts.en:
The Gran Poder (Great Power) group is maD. up of 16 women and three men who live in Sucre, Bolivia. Most of the group members are mothers and have children who are five or older. The group members each have their own businesses: some sell cosmetics, clothing, cold cuts, or cell phones; others work as seamstresses, drivers, and cooks. Most of the group members have between one and five years of experience in their respective businesses. Aleida and Porfiria each have 10 years of experience (Porfiria owns a bus, and Aleida repairs cell phones).

The group members will use their loans to buy more merchandise to sell or materials to produce their various products. The group does not have any previous credit history, either with AgroCapital or at other financial institutions. Their loan officer describes the group as very enterprising and experienced.

loans.use: Buy merchandise or materials for business

loans.name: Salama's Group

texts.en:
This group includes Salama B. from Zanzibar. She is 35 and married with five children, aged nineteen (twins), fifteen, nine, and one. She has been selling charcoal (which is a type of fuel that is commonly used for cooking across Tanzania) for twenty years. She works from 7:00 am - 8:00 pm daily, and currently earns monthly profits of about $80.

This will be Salama's first loan with BRAC. She is hoping to use the loan to buy larger amounts of charcoal in bulk. This will help her sell larger volumes to her customers and make greater profits. Thank you for helping Salama and Mvyuna!

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to expand her business.

loans.name: Zaur

texts.en: Zaur is single and lives in the Azerbaijan town of Khachmaz. He was born in 1985, and went into business as a farmer five years ago. He is applying for a loan of $1,200 to buy fertilizer, pesticides and seeds.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, pesticides and seeds

loans.name: Ulises

texts.es: Ulises tiene 34 años, es casado, vive con su esposa y su hijo. Se dedica a la venta de fertilizantes desde hace un año, lo que aprendió gracias a un buen amigo que lo ayudó mucho para salir adelante. Además, Ulises es cantante,  y pertenece a un grupo musical folclórico de su ciudad. Le agrada vender  y aprender del negocio de los fertilizantes, ya que es muy rentable, puesto que hay una muy buena cantidad de agricultores que llegan a la ciudad en busca de estos productos para sus terrenos de cultivo. Lo difícil es pesar estos fertilizantes en pocas cantidades, ya que tiene un olor muy desagradable. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP. Ulises invertirá 1000 soles en la compra de mayor cantidad de fertilizantes para incrementar sus ventas y sus ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Ulises is 34 years old, is married and lives with his wife and son. He sells fertilizer for a living and has been doing this for the last year. He learned the job thanks to a good friend who helped him get ahead in life. Ulises is also a singer and he belongs to a folkloric music group in his city. He likes being a salesman and learning the fertilizer business. It is a profitable job because there are large numbers of farmers who come to the city to buy fertilizers for their fields. The difficult part of his job is to weigh the fertilizer in small quantities because it has a very disagreeable smell. This is his first loan with MFP. Ulises will invest 1000 soles ($325) in buying more fertilizer so he can increase his sales and his earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the amount of fertilizer to sell

loans.name: Naing

texts.en: Naing K. is 29 years old and resides in Pursat Province. She makes a living growing rice crops. In addition, Naing is also a housewife and takes care of her two children, both of whom are still young and attend school. She is married to Eang Vanna, 39, who helps her in the farming business and earns additional income catching fish from different lakes in the area for sale in the market. He currently earns approximately US$4 a day, which helps the family to pay for food and the children's school fees. Mrs. K. would like to take out a loan to be able to purchase a second-hand motorcycle for her husband to use in his business and for the family's own transportation needs.

loans.use: Purchase of a second-hand motorcycle

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Phan C. is 23 years old and lives with her husband and one child in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She stays at home doing housework and cooks for her family members. Her husband currently earns $5 a day by operating a moto-taxi around the village market. Phan would like this loan so that she can replace an old and unreliable bike with a new, reliable one for her husband to run as a taxi. The old bike is fixed much too often and uses a lot of gas when the motor is operating. (Phan is pictured with her husband and her kid)

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike for her husband's taxi business

loans.name: Tembiapo Porâ Group

texts.es:
Comité Tembiapo Porâ se denomina el grupo conformado en fecha 06 de marzo del 2008, gracias a que la actual Directora General Luz Teresa Giménez, se contacto con la asesora comunicándole que ha conseguido juntar a 16 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando con el Programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras ya en el 4º ciclo, todas las integrantes del grupo se encuentran muy contentas trabajando en forma conjunta y solidaria.
El promedio de crédito retirado por cada integrante es de 500.000 Gs.,lo cual va destinado para diferentes actividades tales como venta de ropas de Ao-po´i, venta de  comestibles, venta de mercerías, venta de exhibidores de vidrio, confección de ropas, compra de mercaderías para la despensa (arroz, azúcar, fideos, lácteos, panificados, yerba, etc.),venta de artículos de librería, venta de accesorios para peluquería, manicura y pedicuro, venta de lencerías, etc.
Todas ellas están muy conformes trabajando con la Fundación Paraguaya.

Este grupo tiene 16 integrantes pero en este ciclo solo 15 solicitaron un prestamo.  La lista abajo incluye todos los integrantes. 

Nombre y Apellido	Actividad
Luz Giménez	Venta de Ao - po´i
Raquel Olmedo 	Venta de Ao - po´i
Liz O.	Venta de lencerías
Blanca L.	Venta de bebidas
María S.	Venta de exhibidores de vidrio
María C.	Venta de  comidas y bebidas
Isabel V.	Despensa
Catalina V.	Costurera
Claudia A.	Venta de comidas y bebidas
Maura V. 	Venta de mercerías y cubiertos.
Dora R.	Venta de mercerías.
Olga Z.	Venta de artículos de librería
Eulalia V.	Costurera
Gertrudis V.	Venta de ropas
Lourdes C.	Peluquería, manicuro y pedicuro
María Q.	Venta de comidas
texts.en:
The Tembiapo Porâ Group was founded on March 6, 2008, thanks to Director Luz Teresa Giménez, who had contacted the adviser to communicate that she had gathered 16 women through the Women Entrepreneurs Group, now in it's 4th cycle. All of the group participants are delighted to be working together and in solidatirty.

El promedio de crédito retirado por cada integrante es de 500.000 Gs.,lo cual va destinado para diferentes actividades tales como venta de ropas de Ao-po´i, venta de comestibles, venta de mercerías, venta de exhibidores de vidrio, confección de ropas, compra de mercaderías para la despensa (arroz, azúcar, fideos, lácteos, panificados, yerba, etc.),venta de artículos de librería, venta de accesorios para peluquería, manicura y pedicuro, venta de lencerías, etc. Todas ellas están muy conformes trabajando con la Fundación Paraguaya. Este grupo tiene 16 integrantes pero en este ciclo solo 15 solicitaron un prestamo. La lista abajo incluye todos los integrantes. Nombre y Apellido Actividad Luz Giménez Venta de Ao - po´i Raquel Olmedo Venta de Ao - po´i Liz O. Venta de lencerías Blanca L. Venta de bebidas María S. Venta de exhibidores de vidrio María C. Venta de comidas y bebidas Isabel V. Despensa Catalina V. Costurera Claudia A. Venta de comidas y bebidas Maura V. Venta de mercerías y cubiertos. Dora R. Venta de mercerías. Olga Z. Venta de artículos de librería Eulalia V. Costurera Gertrudis V. Venta de ropas Lourdes C. Peluquería, manicuro y pedicuro María Q. Venta de comidas

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise (rice, sugar, greens, dairy products,  breads, sodas, other drinks, ingredients, fabric and needles for clothesmaking, notions, Ao-po´i clothes, books, hair and nail care products, glass, linnens, etc.

loans.name: Rosa Amanda

texts.es: Rosa Amanda López tiene 55 años de edad, su estado civil es casada. Doña Rosa tiene 5 hijos y todos sus hijos estudian y trabajan. La actividad económica de Doña Rosa es la venta de comida. Hace más de 12 años que se dedica a este negocio ella nos cuenta que ofrecer este tipo de servicio le gusta en negocio esta ubicado en su casa de habitación y esta dirigida por ella personalmente. Los propósitos de Doña Rosa son de mejorar la calidad de sus comidas por lo que sus clientes buscan la buena comida. El financiamiento es destinado para capital de trabajo para obtener las compras de granos básicos, verduras, carnes, leña y carbón. Los deseos de Doña Rosa son de darle las mejores condiciones a su negocio para que este se ampliara con la ayuda de los financiamientos. La cantidad que solicita es de C$ 10.000 córdobas.
texts.en:
Rosa Amanda López is 55 and married. Doña Rosa has 5 children, all of whom study and work. Doña Rosa sells food for a living. She has done this for more than 12 years, and she tells us that she likes offering this type of service. Her business is located in her home and is managed by her personally. Her goals are to improve the quality of her food because her customers look for good food. This loan will go towards working capital so she can obtain basic grains, vegetables, meat, firewood, and charcoal. Her dreams are to improve her business so she can expand it with the help of these credits. She is requesting 10,000 córdobas.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ni Nengah Tarmin

texts.id: Enam bulan yang lalu Ni Nengah Tarmin mengikuti program  ternak babi yang ada Dinari. Awalnya Ni Nengah Tarmin berencana menggunakan uang pinjaman tersebut untuk membeli indu dan anak babi. Namun karna induk babi harganya cukup mahal, jadi Ni Nengah Tarmin menggunakannya untuk membeli anak babi saja. Di periode pertama Ni Nengah Tarmin mendapat keuntungan yang cukup banyak. Oleh karena itu kini Ni Nengah Tarmin mengajukan pinjaman kedua untuk menambah modalnya membeli anak babi. Ni Nengah Tarmin berharap melalui pinjaman kedua ini, Dia dapat membeli anak babi yang lebih banyak lagi. Sehingga pada saat panen nanti, Dia dapat memperoleh keuntungan yang lebih besar lagi.
texts.en:
Six months ago Ni Nengah Tarmin participated in the Dinari pig farming program. Initially she was planning to use the loan money to buy a breeding pig and several piglets. However due to the breeding pig was expensive, she then used the money to buy only the piglets.

With this Dinari program, Ni Nengah Tarmin was able to earn a considerable amount of profit. Therefore she wants to participate in a second Dinari loan program. This time she wants to buy more piglets so she can earn more profit.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy piglets and pig foods

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: A Kompong Chnang Resident, K. Sina is 29 years old and lives with her 40-year-old husband, Khem Phat, who is a teacher at Soramrith high school. She works hard as a grocery seller and earns a daily income of $3.50 while her husband earns $4 a day. They have two kids and have monthly expenses that are a bit high comparing to their current income. K. Sina is optimistic that if she takes the second loan before the Khmer New Year, it will be possible to buy more goods such as rice, orange juice, beer, and gasoline for her store and to sell it well because the store is conveniently located in the center of the village, and it has been open for 3-4 years already.  As a result, her income will increase due to the plentiful amount of the goods sold. Moreover, she is now trying to save more money and pay everything in order to newly build a house. (K. Sina pictured with her daughter)

loans.use: buy more inventory

loans.name: Van's Group

texts.en:
Vân Phương Thị Vũ was born in 1974. She lives with her husband and two children (with one going to school). Her husband is a painter. She sells clothes in the market. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. She wants to borrow 5,886,000 VND (or $335 US) to buy more clothes to sell. No: 010117090014.  

There are four other fund participants in her group:

Bình Thị Đào was born in 1978. Her family has a beer shop. They have a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND (or $355 US) to repair her house. No: 010117090013. 

Phúc Thị Vương was born in 1962. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND (or $355 US) to buy food for fish. No: 010117090006. 

Quyên Thị Dương was born in 1969. She and her husband are assistants. They have a monthly income of about 3,500,000 VND. She wants to borrow 5,886,000 VND (or $335 US) to breed pigs and poultry. No: 010117090012. 

Luyến K. Thị Lê was born in 1972. She has a monthly income of about 2,500,000 VND. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND (or $355 US) to buy a mowing-machine. No: 010117090007.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia A. is fifty–two years old. She is a divorced mother of three children – a son and two daughters. She says the first born is a teacher while the other two are in the polytechnic and senior high school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a very busy commercial town called Goaso in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana.

Lydia is a trader. She trades in ladies slippers and footwear. She buys from Kumasi and hawks her wares to sell. Lydia says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Lydia has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to procure a variety of footwear in bulk. She is hopeful to expand her business and increase her profit margin. It is Lydia’s desire to sponsor a higher education for her children.

loans.use: Buy footwear in bulk

loans.name: Chem

texts.en: Chem K. is 39 years old and resides in Phnom Penh, where she has had a job as a local carver for years. She normally buys marble blocks in bulk from her suppliers who bring them to her house. She carves them into statues and sells them to people who come to buy at her home. She was married, but divorced her husband when her kids were very young. At the moment, she has two children who attend school and they help her in carving statues. Chem K. will be using a loan for capital to purchase extra marble to make more statues for sale.

loans.use: To purchase extra marble

loans.name: Elsy

texts.es: Elsy tiene 40 años, se dedica a la venta de comestibles en la pequeña tienda que tiene en su casa, además posee un puesto en el mercado. Ella vive con su esposo Basilio quien es soldador y sus hijos Larri de 17 y Sara de 8 años. Desde hace 7 años se ha venido dedicando a esta actividad con la cual se siente muy contenta, ya que tiene la comodidad de realizarla en su propia casa. Además de comestibles también vende artículos de limpieza y de tocador, satisfaciendo la demanda de los clientes, ya que es la única tienda cercana en su vecindario, las ganancias son buenas. Elsy está progresando poco a poco, pero tener que atender su otro negocio en el mercado hace que el día se le haga corto y muy cansado, además los ingresos en su puesto no van bien, porque tiene que pagar la vigilancia y el alquiler, donde se le van casi todas las ganancias. Es así que ha decidido dedicarse netamente a atender la tienda que tiene en su casa, además esto le dará la ventaja de poder cuidar a sus hijos, especialmente a la pequeña que está en edad escolar y necesita de su apoyo. Elsy quiere progresar, es por eso que necesita arreglar su tienda para darles mayor comodidad a sus clientes y por ende vender en mayor tranquilidad. Con Microfinanzas PRISMA viene trabajando hace varios años, siendo este su préstamo número 16, gustándole mucho el trabajo en su banco comunal, ya que todos los miembros son muy unidos y honestos. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería para implementar su tienda, además de realizar algunos arreglos al local para hacerlo más cómodo y atractivo a la clientela.
texts.en:
Elsy, 40, sells food from the small store that she has in her house. She also has a stand in the market. She lives with her husband, Basilio, a solderer; and her children Larri, 17; and Sara, 8. She has been in her business for seven years. She is very happy because she has the comfort of working in her own house. Besides selling food, she also sells cleaning and bathroom products to satisfy her customers’ needs. Because she is the only nearby store in her neighborhood, earnings are good. Elsy is progressing little by little, but having to take care of her other business in the market makes the day short. It makes her very tired. Income from her stand is not going well because she has to pay the guards and the rent, which takes almost all of the earnings. That is why she has decided to solely work at the store she has in her house. This also has the advantage of allowing her to care for her children, especially the little one who is school aged and needs her support. Elsy wants to progress. That is why she needs to fix her store to make her customers more comfortable and sell in greater tranquility. She has been working with Mircofinanzas Prisma for various years. This is her 16th loan. She really likes the work in her Community Bank. All of its members are united and honest. She will use the money she is now asking for to buy more merchandise for her store. She will also make some repairs to her store to make it more comfortable and attractive to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise and fix store

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella A. lives in Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 43 years old, separated and her children are all now adults. To make a living, Estrella runs a sari-sari (or variety) store. Estrella has been engaged in business for more than a year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from her work.

In April 2008, Estrella joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid four previous loans from HSPFI. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP to buy additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to help supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell to her customers

loans.name: Carmen Dora

texts.es:
La señora CARMEN DORA S. V. D. C., tiene 56 años, vive en el distrito deL Porvenir  , provincia D. Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco ESPERANZA DEL MAÑANA
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 6to D. primaria, tiene 5 hijos D. 37, 32, 28, 29 y 22 años quienes no depenD. económicamente D. ella.
CARMEN  se dedica a la venta D. productos alimenticios en la bodega D. su casa, como: arroz, azúcar, aceites, jugos, gaseosas, carnes, etc. 
Su primer crédito D. 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió en la compra D. productos D. vitrinas y balanza electrónica, para la bodega D. su casa.
Este crédito D. 1500 nuevos soles lo invertirá en la compra al por mayor D. mas productos alimenticios, en especial productos D. primera necesidad, como: arroz (sacos), azúcar (sacos), aceite (cajas), papel higiénico (paquetes), y también compra D. una congeladora, para vender helados, y sodas heladas.
CARMEN sueña con ampliar su tienda y colocar una fuente D. soda en su casa.
texts.en:
Sra. Carmen Dora S. V. D. C. is 56 years old. She lives in Del Porvenir District in Trujillo Province, Department of Libertad – Perú. She belongs to the Communal Bank “Esperanza del Mañana” (Hope of Tomorrow).

This entrepreneur has a 6th graD. education. She has 5 children (ages 37, 32, 29, 28, and 22) who are all financially independent. Carmen sells food products from the grocery store she operates out of her home, such as rice, sugar, oil, juices, sodas, meat, etc. Her first loan of 300 soles was used to buy display cabinets and an electronic scale for her business.

Carmen is requesting a new loan of 1500 soles to purchase food products wholesale, especially basic necessities such as sacks of rice, bags of sugar, cases of cooking oil, and packets of toilet paper. She will also buy a freezer so that she can sell ice cream and ice cream sodas. She dreams of expanding her store and installing a soda fountain for her home business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise at wholesale & a freezer

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is 49 years old and married to Felipe, a construction worker. They have a nine year old son named Jeffrey and he is already in grade four.  They are six in the family living together with her parents and nieces at Barangay Cutog Grande Reina Mercedes, Isabela.

Jennifer manages a general store business in their village for almost two months. Her income from the business is being used as a rolling capital.  She wanted to borrow a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP10, 000.00.  She is hoping that her business will grow and become productive for the welfare of her family.  She believes that through patience, success awaits in the future.

loans.use: Business Improvement

loans.name: Asomdwie Hene Reba Group

texts.en: Joyce is thirty – two years old. She is married and has give birth to four children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Joyce is a seamstress by profession. She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Asomdwie Hene Reba’, literally meaning, The Prince of Peace is coming. The group members are engaged either in farming and/or trading activities. They sell/supply in their local market and nearby communities. They want a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.es:
Tomasa tiene 33 años de edad, es separada y tiene a su cargo tres hijos de 11, 10 y 6 años de edad; viven en el distrito de Santa Rosa, ubicado a 25 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

La separación de su esposo la motivó a buscar trabajo hace tres años con la finalidad de sustentar a sus hijos, empezó con la venta de pescado en el terminal pesquero de la zona y continúa en esta actividad hasta la actualidad: junto a un grupo de vecinas suelen esperar en el muelle de Pimentel (Balneario ubicado a 10 minutos del distrito) a las embarcaciones que vienen al muelle luego de sus jornadas de pesca para comprarles pescado y venderlo luego en el terminal a diversos comerciantes de la región.

El negocio le brindó temporalmente los ingresos que necesitaba pero las continuas temporadas de veda la hicieron pensar en otro negocio con el cual seguir sustentando a su familia, fue así como instaló en su casa una pequeña bodega – tienda en la cual vende productos de primera necesidad (arroz, azúcar, aceite); frutas, verduras y golosinas.

Este negocio es atendido por su hija mayor por las mañanas y por ella en las tardes; Tomasa aún vende pescado en el terminal pero sin captar los ingresos que antes percibía. Ella desea implementar su tiendita para dejar de vender pescado y dedicarle más tiempo a sus hijos; por este motivo se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en el logro de su objetivo.

Tomasa desea incursionar con la venta de útiles escolares en su negocio, ya que en la zona en donde vive no existe ningún establecimiento de ese tipo y los niños del lugar (incluyendo a sus hijos) tienen que caminar hasta el centro de la ciudad para agenciarse de material de trabajo.

Este es su primer préstamo con Edpyme Alternativa, ella es muy conocida por sus vecinos los cuales la admiran y aprecian ya que es una mujer luchadora que ha sabido sacar adelante a su familia a pesar de las adversidades.
texts.en:
Tomasa is 33 years old, is separated and takes care of her three children who are 11, 10 and 6 years old. They live in the district of Santa Rosa, located 25 minutes of the city of Chiclayo.

The separation from her husband motivated her to look for a job three years ago in order to support her children. She started selling fish in the fishing terminal and continues the activity to this day. Tomasa along with a group of her neighbors, usually wait in the Pimentel pier (Balneario some 10 minutes from the district) for the boats who come to the dock after their fishing workday ends to buy their fish and sell them later in the terminal to various merchants in the region.

The fishing business temporarily gave her the necessary funds to survive but the close season made her consider going into another business to keep supporting her family. She set up in her home a small grocery store, where she sells basic household goods (rice, sugar, and oil); fruits, vegetables and candy.
