This business is taken care of by her eldest daughter in the mornings and by Tomasa in the afternoons. She still sells fish in the terminal but does not gain the same profit as before. She wishes to maintain her store and stop selling fish to dedicate more time to her children. This is why she is asking Edpyme Alternativa (kiva’s field partner) for a loan of 1500 nuevos soles that she will use to meet her goal.

Tomasa wishes to sell school supplies in her business as well, since the place where she lives there aren’t any businesses of this type and the children (including hers) have to walk to the center of the city to get their school supplies.

This will be her first loan with Edpyme Alternativa. Tomasa is very well known by her neighbors who admire and value her since she is a hardworking woman who has been able to give her family a good start in life despite all their hardships.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy groceries and basic household goods to expand her business.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is 41 year single mother of six children aged between 9 and 19 years. All her children go to school .She resides and rents a one roomed house where she stays with five people  Monica takes care of additional family members. The family has no access to electricity and piped water.  Monica works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala.  She owns a retail shop on Lubaga road Social center zone. Monica buys her merchandise from Kikuubo one of the busiest places in Kampala city.  She pays transport costs to and from shopping. She is faced with the challenge of increasing prices of merchandise   hence a reduction in no of customers she receives each day.  Her residence also acts as her business premises .Monica  sells to all categories of people both on retail and whole sale and works seven days a week  She has been in this business for five years and with MCDT for five years servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise for her retail shop like bags of sugar, boxes of soap and cartons of salt. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a whole sale shop.

loans.use: to buy bags of sugar boxes of soap and cartons of salt

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is 53 years old and she manages a food vending business.  Aside from this, she is also selling vegetables in their village and her weekly net income is PHP 300.00.  She is now asking to borrow a loan of PHP 7,000 from the Kiva lenders.  The loan will be used to purchase additional commodities for her stall. She wants to increase her income to support the needs of her family.  

Her husband is a vegetable vendor in their village.  They have three children: Sherylyn, 30 years old, a college graduate; Jackielyn, 26 years old, a cashier in a department store in Manila; and their youngest is Eduardo Jr., 25 years old, a farmer. They are living in Del Corpuz, Cabatuan, Isablela.  She works with patience and industriousness to reach her goal of gaining success.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetables to sell

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita E., 40 years old, is the mother of five children whose ages range from 1 to 12 years old. Her husband is a fisherman while she is a fish vendor. Hand in hand the couple strives to bring their family out of poverty despite the unending obstacles they encounter. As they go through life, the vision of their children is their inspiration. Margarita and her husband want them to finish their education until college to be able to have a better career in the future.

As much as possible, Margarita, being their mother, would not want their children to experience life with less options because of poverty. To be able to achieve this dream, Margarita is working hard to grow her husband’s business as well as her own.

Through her membership in ASHI, loans she accesses are used properly to materialize every plan she and her husband have for the business. Someday, she positively believes that no matter how poor they are now, through their determination, unity and love to one another, they will be able to change their standard of living along and that of their children.

loans.use: To finace their fishing and fish-selling businesses

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 21-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Ibrahim has been working as a taxi driver. He requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase a van for his work. He plans on expanding his work by working also as a school van. This is the first time that Ibrahim has requested a loan.

Ibrahim is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are students, friends, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash and used to work as a driver. Ibrahim decided on doing his business because he didn’t want to work for someone anymore, he wanted to have an independent job. In the future, he plans on expanding his business by purchasing a school van.

loans.use: To purchase a van for his work

loans.name: Mai's Group

texts.en:
Mai Nguyễn Thị (10102080003) is a 47-year-old femaL. living in the town of Đông Anh - Hà nội.  Mai is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by SEDA.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Phố Chợ (3).

Mai is married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, Mai owns & operates a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community.  Mai has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 3.000.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, Mai joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Mai has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2.204.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  She is now requesting a new loan of 4.142.000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  Mai plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  Lê Thị Hương (10102080013) is a 27-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5.014.000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged peopL. in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Mai Nguyễn Thị (10102080003) là 47 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Đông Anh - Hà nội.  Mai là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 2 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Phố Chợ (3).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các mặt hàng nhu yếu phẩm như dầu gội đầu, xà bông & kem đánh răng trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Mai thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Mai kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2007, Mai đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Mai đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 2.204.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4.142.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Lê Thị Hương (10102080013) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.014.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Geovanny Melquiades

texts.en:
Geovanny Melquiades Z. R. lives in the Paraiso district of Guayaquil. He lives in a cement home with water and light; however, it lacks paved roads and a sewer system. He has 3 children, who are aged 7, 8 and 12; all are in the public school system.

Mr. Z. used to work in a food market called Montebello. One day he decided to bring some vegetables home to sell. He sold the products rapidly, so he decided to create a mini market in his home, and little by little it has grown. Now he has expanded it into a bazaar. He works from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. with his wife. Their best-selling items are rice, shampoo and cola.

Mr. Z. is trying to augment the bazaar portion of his store, so he is requesting a loan to buy clothes, stuffed animals and makeup. He says these items are especially popular around the holidays. Transportation of products is a huge obstacle for him, so in the future he hopes to have a vehicle. Any assistance in helping Mr.Z.`s business grow is very much appreciated!

loans.use: To buy clothes, stuffed animals, and makeup

loans.name: Houda

texts.en: Houda has worked as a home-based tailor for the past 10 years. Over the years, thanks to her business income, she was able to cooperate with her husband to provide for her family's needs and pay for her 2 children's schooling. Today, Houda is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy a new sewing machine to help her present a variety of products to her clients.

loans.use: buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita trabaja como comerciante de instrumentos musicales, el esposo es músico. Es  su fuente de ingreso con la que mantiene a su familia. Tienen 4 hijos y tres están a su cargo con las edades de 6, 12 y 15 años. Su domicilio esta ubicado en la Zona  de Rio Seco de la ciudad de El Elto. 

El préstamo lo destinará a la compra de  2 trompetas, 3 platillos y 2 tambores, para su venta a colegios en esta temporada de inicio de clases.
 
Es su cuarto crédito con Impro, el buen comportamiento de pago le permite solicitar otro préstamo.
texts.en:
Margarita sells musical instruments; her husband is a musician. It is her income that supports the family. They have four children, three of whom (aged 6, 12, and 15 years) they still support. Their home is located in the neighbourhood of Rio Seco in the city of El Elto. The loan will be used to buy two trumpets, three sets of cymbals, and two drums to sell at this time of year when high school classes are just starting. This is Margarita’s fourth loan with Kiva partner Impro. Because she showed herself responsible with the repayments of the other loans, she has qualified for another one.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy musical instruments to sell to students

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina P. is 25 and married with 5 children (ages 1 - 12).  She owns a business venture, selling baked goods in the local community.  Selina has 2 years of experience in this business.  Selina needs a loan of WST $1500 to buy raw ingredients for cooked foods.  She plans to use the earnings from her business to assist her family with the business activities such as a food stall for the school canteen.

In 2009, Selina joined SPBD.    This is her 2nd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Selina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Selina P. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                         2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:            2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:                2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for cooked foods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia is a widow with a 22-year-old child. She owns a grocery store which she loves because of the one-on-one interaction she has with her customers. Felicia hopes for a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries to sell and to expand her business. As a hard-working woman with the determination to excel, she hopes to lift her business and family out of poverty. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Kamalawathi

texts.en:
Kamalawathi is a 41-year-old married woman in Kekanadura, Matara area. She has three daughters. Her husband has a masonry business.

Kamalawathi works on her own. She has a plot of land where she grows various fruits, vegetables and other products. She has been doing this business for three years and is known to be a very hard-worker. 

Kamalawathi has requested a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to purchase fertilizer for her land.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Dinina Yuli

texts.es:
Dinina es socia del Banco Comunal Trinidad.
Dinina es casada, tiene 33 años y 1 hijo, Dinina tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, verduras, carnes, actividad que realiza todos los días. Además Dinina se dedica a la agricultura de cereales, productos que vende en la ciudad de Pisco y también Ayacucho. 
Dinina necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, fideos. 
Dinina sueña con tener una tienda grande.
texts.en:
Dinina, 33, is a member of the Trinidad (Trinity) communal bank. She is married and has a son. She has a grocery store in her home where she stocks assorted groceries, vegetables and meats. She is open for business daily. In addition, Dinina farms cereals that she sells in the cities of Pisco and Ayacucho. Dinina needs a 1500 sol loan to buy rice and pasta. Dinina dreams with owning a large store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice and pasta.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 35 years old, married with a child. She is a happy and hard working woman. Mercy is a LAPO client. Mercy has a poultry farm where she rears birds to sell. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. Mercy hopes to expand her poultry business. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more birds. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry birds

loans.name: Simeona

texts.en:
Simeona B., 59, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs.  Happily married to Danilo B., a farmer, they are blessed with 5 children.  Simeona makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been into managing an ornamental and flower raising business while also operating a tricycle unit for seven years now.

Simeona has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than five years now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means she was able to borrow six times from CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business. 

To ensure the success of her business, Simeona would like to apply for a loan of 12,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding businesses for buying additional ornamental plants, needed materials and also buying spare parts for the maintenance of their own tricycle unit.

Simeona dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can buy an additional home lot for their children to settle on someday.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying additional ornamentals, fertilizers, needed materials and spare parts for the maintenance of tricycle unit.

loans.name: Union Y Vida Group

texts.es: El grupo de Union y Vida esta conformado por tres socias, ellas son originarias de Sumpango. La mayoria de señoras de dedican a bordar y tejer. La representante es Olga A., madre de 6 hijos, ella vende ropa tipíca en el municipio y todos los dias viernes viaja a otro municipio para comprar mercadería. Las otras dos integrantes se dedican a bordar blusas, asñi como también a tejer fajas, Olga necesita agrandar su negocio ya que ha tenido ucha demanda, por lo que solicitan otro c´redito, ellas han tenido varios cr´ditos con FAPE, y han pagado muy bien, con el dinero solicitado comprarán ropa para hacer crecer mas su negocio y también comprarán hilo para tejer y bordar mas ropa, ellas sueñan con tener un local propio en donde las busquen y asi mismo incrementar su negocio.
texts.en:
The group “Union y Vida” (Union and Life) consists of three members who are originally from Sumpango. Most of these women engage in embroidery and weaving. Olga A. is the group representative and the mother of six children. She sells traditional clothing in the city and travels to another city every Friday to buy merchandise. The other members make embroidered blouses as well as woven sashes.

Olga needs to expand her business as a result of great demand, which is why she is requesting another loan. These women have had several loans with FAPE and repaid them successfully. The loan they requested will be used to buy clothing to expand Olga’s business as well as acquire more yarn for producing embroidered and woven clothing. They dream of having a store where customers can find them and they can grow their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Ana Julia

texts.es:
Todos los días desde las cuatro de la mañana, la señora Ana Julia llega al mercado Mayoreo con las naranjas dispuesta a venderlas todas y así obtener ingresos para el mejoramiento del nivel de vida de su familia.

Ella es una dama muy trabajadora y anhela continuar en dicha labor para el mantenimiento de su hogar. El crédito lo está solicitando para la compra de dichas naranjas y así continuar en su labor.
texts.en:
Every day at four in the morning, la señora Ana Julia arrives at the Mayoreo market ready to sell all her oranges. Her sales generate income to improve her family's standard of living. She is a very hard-working woman and wishes to continue with this work to pay household expenses. This loan will be used to buy oranges for resale.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of oranges

loans.name: Maricris

texts.en: Maricris C. runs a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling both food and daily use products in her community. She is 36 years old, married and has five school-age children. They are from the village of Malinao, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. Maricris has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Maricris joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Maricris is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Juliette

texts.fr: D. Juliette est née le 18 Mai 1967 au Mono. Juliette n'est pas mariée mais a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Juliette vit seule depuis deux ans à Agla à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Juliette vend des chaussures et également des tenues (friperies) dans son quartier. Juliette s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et à Lomé au Togo. Juliette exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans et a déjà bénéficié de quatre prêts à ALIDé, prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Juliette désire rehausser le niveau de son activité et accroître davantage sa clientèle et par ricochet son chiffre d'affaire. C'est pourquoi Juliette sollicite un autre crédit.
texts.en:
Juliette D. was born on May 18, 1967, in Mono. She's unmarried but has two school-attending children. For two years, she's been living alone in Agla in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. To provide for herself, Juliette sells shoes and second hand clothing in her neighborhood. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, an international marketplace in Benin, as well as in Lomé, Togo. Juliette has been running this business for five years, and already obtained four loans from Kiva's partner, ALIDé. All loans were repaid without problems. She would like to bolster her business and increase her clientele and, consequently, her revenue. This is why she's seeking another loan.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shoes and clothing

loans.name: Marites

texts.en: Marites C. is from the village of Tupsan, Pequeño, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old. Marites is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Marites operates a mini-restaurant. The main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 9,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Marites joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. This will be the first loan taken out by Marites from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food and drinks for the restaurant

loans.name: Mónica

texts.es:
Mónica V. G. cuenta con un negocio de papelería y mercería llamado “Mónica” con este negocio tiene un año para incrementar sus ingresos también  cuenta con una peluquería llamada “Ramírez”. La señora es una mujer muy trabajadora a pesar de ser madre soltera ha podido sacar a sus hijos adelante,  pensando en ofréceles una mejor calidad de vida.
Mónica solicita que se le apoye para surtir su negocio ya que se aproxima compra de listas escolares.
texts.en:
Mónica V. G. has a stationery and haberdashery shop called "Mónica”. She has given herself a year to increase her income from this business. She also has a hairdressing salon called “Ramírez”. She is a very hard-working woman. Although she is a single mother she has been able to bring up her children, and is always thinking of how she can offer them a better life. Mónica is seeking the loan to stock up her business with school supplies.

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her business

loans.name: Jamilatu

texts.en:
Jamilatu W. is married to a carpenter and lives with her husband and two children. She has no formal educational background.

Jamilatu sells provisions at Elmina. She will use the loan to purchase extra provisions to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to set up another provisions shop in Abura market.

loans.use: To purchase extra provisions to sell

loans.name: Elba Ruth

texts.es: Elba Ruth tiene mucho tiempo de ser clientes de Fundación, por lo que no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos. Sus tres hijos han crecido y son independientes. Ella se dedica a un comedor desde hace más 37 años su negocio nació con la idea de establecerlo en un lugar fijo en donde la mayoría de sus clientes llegaran a disfrutar de lo que ofrece. Este  crédito es para la compra de granos básicos, jugos, gaseosas, verduras entre otras cosas. Sueña con seguir creciendo y manteniendo este negocio que hasta los momentos es el único medio de vida que posee.
texts.en:
Elba Ruth has been a client of Fundación Leon 2000 for a long time, so this is not the first time she has received a loan. Her three children are grown and independent. Elba has been managing a diner for more than 37 years. Her business started as a result of an idea she had to own an established location where most of her customers could come to enjoy the food she offers.

This loan will be used to buy basic grains, juices, soft drinks, vegetables, and other items. She hopes to continue growing and maintaining her business since this is the only means of earning a living that she has.

loans.use: Purchase basic grains, juices, soft drinks, vegetables, and other items

loans.name: Sary

texts.en:
Sary S., 36 years old, is a humble villager living in Kompong Chhnang Province. She is married and blessed with three school-aged children; her husband is a car taxi driver. To earn a living, Sary S. sells a few items such as charcoal and coconut which she buys in bulk from her supplier. Her husband always picks up the products for her before he starts providing his taxi service. 

Currently, Sary S. wishes to have more funds to increase her capital which will allow her to increase her profit. That is why she has decided to look for lenders on Kiva to purchase some sugar and charcoal for expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase some sugar and charcoal to expand her business

loans.name: Ninoska

texts.es:
Ninoska es una exitosa madre soltera de 3 hijos, ella quiere probarse a si misma que puede administrar y hacer crecer su negocio con mayor éxito.
Ella es de Canalete de Alajuela, una comunidad caracterizada por el liderazgo de las mujeres  que  la habitan.
Hace 7 años empezó a trabajar en una tienda de  por departamento hasta hace poco que logro obtener su propia tiendita donde vende todo tipo de ropa para mujer. Hoy ella necesita un préstamo de ₡604 000 (Seiscientos Cuatro mil colones) para la compra de ropa interior, perfumes, cosméticos que podrá comercializar en su tiendita. Con el préstamo espera tener mayor mercancía y así darle un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
Ella es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Canalete, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica .Este será su primer crédito.
texts.en:
Ninoska is a successful single mother with 3 children.  She would like to test herself and show that she can run and grow her business more successfully.

She is from Canalete de Alajuela, a community which is noted for the leadership of the women who live in it.

7 years ago Ninoska started working in a department store.  A short time ago she managed to obtain her own small store where she sells all kinds of women's clothing.  Today she needs a loan for 604,000 colones to buy underwear, perfume and cosmetics which she can sell in her store.  With her loan she hopes to have more merchandise and thereby provide her customers with a better service.

Ninoska is a member of the Canalete Communal Credit Company (Empresa de Crédito Comunal Canalete), one of the 100 partner organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica.  This will be her first loan.

loans.use: Perfume and underwear

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophea S., 40 and her husband, Proeung Un, 46, have been married since 1989 and have one son and two daughters. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sophea is a silk weaver. Her husband is a farmer. She is requesting a loan of US $300 to purchase weaving materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials

loans.name: Rosina

texts.en:
Rosina is married and has five children between the ages of 9 and 20 years. She has been in mixed farming for seven years. She produces eggs, milk, tea, and vegetables and sells them locally. Her challenges are animal diseases and limited access to poultry feeds. 

She has applied for this loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She plans to use the income to pay school fees for her children. She gets additional income from her retail shop business. She wants to expand her poultry business in five years to a volume of 100 chickens.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Marcelo

texts.en:
Marcelo B. is from the village of Bagong Tanza. He is 60 years old, married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Marcelo raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Marcelo has been engaged in his business for over 38 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Marcelo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marcelo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Marcelo is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will again be used to purchase fertilizer. This loan will be Marcelo's 7th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz E. is a widow who lives in Purok Tan-ao, Brgy Lopez Jaena, Sagay City, Negros Occidental.  She earns her living by operating a buy and sell of ready-to-wear clothes business and a general store.  She has four children who are 32 to 38 years old. Luz joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family.  With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Luz has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her general store and ready-to-wear clothes businesses so that she can continue to save up for future house improvements.  Luz E. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.
"

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Celia

texts.es:
Celia, tiene 59 años, es casada y tiene tres hijos, ella nació en la provincia del Cusco departamento del Cusco y actualmente vive junto con su esposo en la misma ciudad. 

Celia es profesora cesante pero todavía trabaja como profesora en la institución educativa privada “Leoncio Padro” y en este momento se encuentra D. vacaciones. Ya son 10 años que trabaja en el colegio y le va muy bien. Celia también tiene una tienda D. abarrotes, ella durante sus vacaciones abre desD. muy temprano y durante resto del año solo en las noches. 
 
Celia espera recibir $ 900 USD D. crédito y utilizará este dinero para comprar mercadería como por ejemplo cerveza, arroz, gaseosas, agua mineral, etc. El sueño D. Celia ampliar su tienda o abrir otro tienda. 

Celia pertenece al banco comunal “Velasco Astete” D. la UMF Asociación Arariwa. El banco comunal esta en el noveno año D. funcionamiento y está bien administrado por la junta directiva.
texts.en:
Celia, aged 59, is married and the mother of three children. She was born in the province of Cusco, department of Cusco, and currently lives with her husband in her native city.

Celia is a teacher who was laid off, but she still works as a teacher in the private school "Leoncio Padro". Currently she is on vacation. She has already worked for ten years in this school and is doing very well. Celia owns also a grocery store; during her vacations she opens it very early and during the rest of the year only in the evenings.

Celia expects to be granted a loan of US$900 which she will use to buy goods such as beer, rice, soft drinks, mineral water, etc.  Celia's dream is to expand her store or open another one.

Celia is a member of the communal bank "Velasco Astete" of the microfinance unit Asociación Arariwa. The communal bank is in its ninth year of operation and is well managed by its Board.

loans.use: To buy goods such as beer, rice, soft drinks, mineral water, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorbike for one of her children to operate a new business
